verses.sanskrit: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच। धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः। मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय॥
verses.transliteration: dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca | dharma-kṣetre kuru-kṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ | māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāś caiva kim akurvata sañjaya ||
verses.translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, after my sons and the sons of Pandu assembled in the place of pilgrimage at Kurukshetra, desiring to fight, what did they do?
verses.teaching: The opening verse sets the stage for the great dialogue. Kurukshetra represents both the external battlefield and the internal field of dharma where the battle between good and evil takes place within each person.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच। दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा। आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत्॥
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca | dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṁ vyūḍhaṁ duryodhanas tadā | ācāryam upasaṅgamya rājā vacanam abravīt ||
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: O King, after looking over the army arranged in military formation by the sons of Pandu, King Duryodhana went to his teacher and spoke the following words.
verses.teaching: This verse shows how in times of crisis, even the proud seek guidance from their teachers. It highlights the importance of seeking counsel from experienced mentors.

verses.sanskrit: पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम्। व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता॥
verses.transliteration: paśyaitāṁ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīṁ camūm | vyūḍhāṁ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā ||
verses.translation: O my teacher, behold the great army of the sons of Pandu, so expertly arranged by your intelligent disciple Dhrishtadyumna, the son of Drupada.
verses.teaching: Duryodhana acknowledges the skill of his enemies, showing that wisdom recognizes merit even in opponents. This teaches us to respect competence regardless of personal conflicts.

verses.sanskrit: अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि। युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः॥
verses.transliteration: atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi | yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca drupadaś ca mahā-rathaḥ ||
verses.translation: Here in this army are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhima and Arjuna: great fighters like Yuyudhana, Virata and Drupada.
verses.teaching: Recognition of strength in opponents is a mark of wisdom. Acknowledging others' abilities without diminishing our own confidence shows mature assessment.

verses.sanskrit: पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः। पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः॥
verses.transliteration: pāñcajanyaṁ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṁ dhanañjayaḥ | pauṇḍraṁ dadhmau mahā-śaṅkhaṁ bhīma-karmā vṛkodaraḥ ||
verses.translation: Lord Krishna blew His conchshell Panchajanya; Arjuna blew his, called Devadatta; and Bhima the terrible blew his great shell called Paundra.
verses.teaching: The divine sound of conchshells represents the call to righteous action. When we align with dharma, even our preparations become sacred and announce the victory of good over evil.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत। यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान्॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca | senayor ubhayor madhye rathaṁ sthāpaya me 'cyuta | yāvad etān nirīkṣe 'haṁ yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O infallible one, please place my chariot between the two armies so that I may see those present here, who desire to fight.
verses.teaching: Sometimes we need to pause and assess a situation fully before acting. Taking time to understand what we're facing is a sign of wisdom, not weakness.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम्। सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca | dṛṣṭvemaṁ sva-janaṁ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṁ samupasthitam | sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṁ ca pariśuṣyati ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: My dear Krishna, seeing my friends and relatives present before me in such a fighting spirit, I feel the limbs of my body quivering and my mouth drying up.
verses.teaching: Physical symptoms often reflect mental and spiritual conflicts. Our body responds to moral dilemmas, showing the deep connection between conscience and physical well-being.

verses.sanskrit: न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे। न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च॥
verses.transliteration: na ca śreyo 'nupaśyāmi hatvā sva-janam āhave | na kāṅkṣe vijayaṁ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṁ sukhāni ca ||
verses.translation: I can find no good in killing my own kinsmen in battle, nor can I, my dear Krishna, desire any subsequent victory, kingdom, or happiness.
verses.teaching: When personal relationships conflict with duty, we may question whether any gain is worth the cost. This moral sensitivity shows the depth of Arjuna's character.

verses.sanskrit: अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः। स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः॥
verses.transliteration: adharmābhibhavāt kṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kula-striyaḥ | strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya jāyate varṇa-saṅkaraḥ ||
verses.translation: When irreligion is prominent in the family, O Krishna, the women of the family become polluted, and from the degradation of womanhood, O descendant of Vrishni, comes unwanted progeny.
verses.teaching: Arjuna expresses concern about social breakdown following war. His worry shows how individual actions can have far-reaching consequences on society and future generations.

verses.sanskrit: एवमुक्त्वार्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत्। विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः॥
verses.transliteration: evam uktvārjunaḥ saṅkhye rathopastha upāviśat | visṛjya sa-śaraṁ cāpaṁ śoka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ ||
verses.translation: Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.
verses.teaching: This verse shows the climax of Arjuna's crisis. Sometimes we must reach the depths of confusion before we can receive divine guidance. It sets the stage for Krishna's teachings.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच। तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम्। विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः॥
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca | taṁ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭam aśru-pūrṇākulekṣaṇam | viṣīdantam idaṁ vākyam uvāca madhusūdanaḥ ||
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Seeing Arjuna full of compassion, his mind depressed, his eyes full of tears, Madhusudana, Krishna, spoke the following words.
verses.teaching: Krishna responds to Arjuna's emotional crisis with wisdom. This shows that divine guidance comes when we are most receptive, often in our moments of greatest need.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम्। अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca | kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṁ viṣame samupasthitam | anārya-juṣṭam asvargyam akīrti-karam arjuna ||
verses.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: My dear Arjuna, how have these impurities come upon you? They are not at all befitting a man who knows the value of life. They lead not to higher planets but to infamy.
verses.teaching: Krishna challenges Arjuna's despondency, calling it 'impurity' that doesn't befit a noble person. Sometimes we need direct confrontation with our weaknesses to move forward.

verses.sanskrit: क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते। क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप॥
verses.transliteration: klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate | kṣudraṁ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṁ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa ||
verses.translation: O son of Pritha, do not yield to this degrading impotence. It does not become you. Give up such petty weakness of heart and arise, O chastiser of the enemy!
verses.teaching: Krishna calls for courage and action over despair. True strength comes from rising above emotional weakness and taking appropriate action despite difficulties.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। कथं भीष्ममहं सङ्ख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन। इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca | kathaṁ bhīṣmam ahaṁ saṅkhye droṇaṁ ca madhusūdana | iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāv arisūdana ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Madhusudana, how can I counterattack with arrows in battle men like Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of my worship?
verses.teaching: The conflict between personal respect and duty creates deep moral anguish. Sometimes life demands actions that seem to contradict our deepest values and relationships.

verses.sanskrit: गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान्श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके। हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान्रुधिरप्रदिग्धान्॥
verses.transliteration: gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṁ bhaikṣyam apīha loke | hatvārtha-kāmāṁs tu gurūn ihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān ||
verses.translation: It would be better to live in this world by begging than to live at the cost of the lives of great souls who are my teachers. Though they are avaricious, they are nonetheless superiors. If they are killed, everything we enjoy will be tainted with blood.
verses.teaching: Arjuna values his teachers above material gain. True respect for mentors means not harming them even when they oppose us. Some victories come at too high a moral cost.

verses.sanskrit: न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः। यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषामस्ते वस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः॥
verses.transliteration: na caitad vidmaḥ kataran no garīyo yad vā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ | yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te 'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ ||
verses.translation: Nor can we tell which would be better—conquering them or being conquered by them. If we killed the sons of Dhritarashtra, we would not want to live.
verses.teaching: Some situations present no clear winning option. When all choices lead to suffering, we need wisdom beyond ordinary calculation to find the right path.

verses.sanskrit: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः। यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्॥
verses.transliteration: kārpaṇya-doṣopahata-svabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṁ dharma-sammūḍha-cetāḥ | yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṁ brūhi tan me śiṣyas te 'haṁ śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam ||
verses.translation: In pity lost, by doubtings tossed, my thoughts—distracted—turn to Thee, the Guide I reverence most, that I may counsel learn: I know not what would heal the grief burned into soul and sense, if I were earth's unchallenged chief—a god—and these gone thence!
verses.teaching: Arjuna surrenders to Krishna as his spiritual teacher, acknowledging his confusion about dharma. True learning begins with humility and the recognition that we need guidance from those wiser than ourselves.

verses.sanskrit: न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्यात्यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम्। अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम्॥
verses.transliteration: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām | avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṁ rājyaṁ surāṇām api cādhipatyam ||
verses.translation: I can find no means to drive away this grief which is drying up my senses. I will not be able to dispel it even if I win a prosperous, unrivaled kingdom on earth with sovereignty like that of the gods in heaven.
verses.teaching: Material success cannot heal spiritual wounds. When our conscience is troubled, external achievements feel meaningless. True peace must be found within.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच। एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप। न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह॥
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca | evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśaṁ guḍākeśaḥ parantapa | na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṁ babhūva ha ||
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus, Arjuna, chastiser of enemies, told Govinda, 'I will not fight,' and fell silent.
verses.teaching: Sometimes we reach a point of complete decision - right or wrong. Arjuna's definitive refusal shows he has moved from confusion to a firm (though misguided) resolve.

verses.sanskrit: तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत। सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः॥
verses.transliteration: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasann iva bhārata | senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṁ vacaḥ ||
verses.translation: O descendant of Bharata, at that time Krishna, smiling, in the midst of both the armies, spoke the following words to the grief-stricken Arjuna.
verses.teaching: Krishna's smile suggests compassionate understanding rather than mockery. A true teacher remains calm and even joyful when guiding someone through their darkest moments.

verses.sanskrit: अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे। गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः॥
verses.transliteration: aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṁ prajñā-vādāṁś ca bhāṣase | gatāsūn agatāsūṁś ca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ ||
verses.translation: Thou grievest where no grief should be! thou speak'st words lacking wisdom! for the wise in heart mourn not for those that live, nor those that die.
verses.teaching: True wisdom lies in understanding the eternal nature of the soul. The wise do not grieve for the temporary changes of the body, knowing the soul is imperishable.

verses.sanskrit: न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः। न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम्॥
verses.transliteration: na tv evāhaṁ jātu nāsaṁ na tvaṁ neme janādhipāḥ | na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param ||
verses.translation: Nor I, nor thou, nor any one of these, ever was not, nor ever will not be, for ever and for ever afterwards.
verses.teaching: The soul is eternal - it has no beginning and no end. This fundamental truth about our divine nature should eliminate fear of death and attachment to the temporary body.

verses.sanskrit: देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा। तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति॥
verses.transliteration: dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā | tathā dehāntara-prāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati ||
verses.translation: All, that doth live, lives always! To man's frame as there come infancy and youth and age, so come there raisings-up and layings-down of other and of other life-abodes, which the wise know, and fear not.
verses.teaching: Just as the soul passes through childhood, youth and old age in one body, it similarly passes from one body to another. The wise are not bewildered by this process.

verses.sanskrit: मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः। आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत॥
verses.transliteration: mātrā-sparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkha-dāḥ | āgamāpāyino 'nityās tāṁs titikṣasva bhārata ||
verses.translation: This that irks thy sense-life, thrilling to the elements—bringing thee heat and cold, sorrows and joys, 'tis brief and mutable! Bear with it, Prince!
verses.teaching: Sensory experiences of pleasure and pain, heat and cold are temporary and come and go like seasons. The wise person learns to tolerate them with equanimity.

verses.sanskrit: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ। समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते॥
verses.transliteration: yaṁ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṁ puruṣarṣabha | sama-duḥkha-sukhaṁ dhīraṁ so 'mṛtatvāya kalpate ||
verses.translation: As the wise bear. The soul which is not moved, the soul that with a strong and constant calm takes sorrow and takes joy indifferently, lives in the life undying!
verses.teaching: One who remains undisturbed by pleasure and pain, and treats them equally, becomes eligible for liberation and immortality.

verses.sanskrit: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः। उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः॥
verses.transliteration: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ | ubhayor api dṛṣṭo 'ntas tv anayos tattva-darśibhiḥ ||
verses.translation: That which is can never cease to be; that which is not will not exist. To see this truth of both is theirs who part essence from accident, substance from shadow.
verses.teaching: The unreal has no existence, and the real never ceases to be. Those who can discern between the temporary and eternal understand this fundamental truth.

verses.sanskrit: अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्। विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति॥
verses.transliteration: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṁ tatam | vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati ||
verses.translation: Indestructible, learn thou! the Life is, spreading life through all; it cannot anywhere, by any means, be anywise diminished, stayed, or changed.
verses.teaching: Know that which pervades the entire body is indestructible. No one can destroy the imperishable soul that animates all living beings.

verses.sanskrit: अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः। अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत॥
verses.transliteration: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ | anāśino 'prameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata ||
verses.translation: But for these fleeting frames which it informs with spirit deathless, endless, infinite, they perish. Let them perish, Prince! and fight!
verses.teaching: Only the physical bodies are perishable, while the soul dwelling within is eternal, indestructible and immeasurable. Therefore, do your duty without hesitation.

verses.sanskrit: य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम्। उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते॥
verses.transliteration: ya enaṁ vetti hantāraṁ yaś cainaṁ manyate hatam | ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṁ hanti na hanyate ||
verses.translation: He who shall say, 'Lo! I have slain a man!' He who shall think, 'Lo! I am slain!' those both know naught! Life cannot slay. Life is not slain!
verses.teaching: Neither the soul kills nor can it be killed. Those who think they are the killer or the killed are both ignorant of the soul's eternal nature.

verses.sanskrit: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः। अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे॥
verses.transliteration: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṁ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṁ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre ||
verses.translation: Never the spirit was born; the spirit shall cease to be never; never was time it was not; End and Beginning are dreams! Birthless and deathless and changeless remaineth the spirit for ever; death hath not touched it at all, dead though the house of it seems!
verses.teaching: The soul is never born, nor does it die. It is unborn, eternal, permanent, and primeval. It is not destroyed when the body is destroyed.

verses.sanskrit: वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम्। कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम्॥
verses.transliteration: vedāvināśinaṁ nityaṁ ya enam ajam avyayam | kathaṁ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṁ ghātayati hanti kam ||
verses.translation: Who knoweth it exhaustless, self-sustained, immortal, indestructible,—shall such say, 'I have killed a man, or caused to kill?'
verses.teaching: One who truly knows the soul to be indestructible, eternal, unborn and unchanging - how can such a person kill anyone or cause anyone to be killed?

verses.sanskrit: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि। तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णान्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही॥
verses.transliteration: vāsāṁsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro 'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāny anyāni saṁyāti navāni dehī ||
verses.translation: Nay, but as when one layeth his worn-out robes away, and taking new ones, sayeth, 'These will I wear to-day!' so putteth by the spirit lightly its garb of flesh, and passeth to inherit a residence afresh.
verses.teaching: Just as a person sheds worn-out clothes and wears new garments, the soul casts off worn-out bodies and enters new ones. This natural process should not be a cause for grief.

verses.sanskrit: नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः। न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः॥
verses.transliteration: nainaṁ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṁ dahati pāvakaḥ | na cainaṁ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ ||
verses.translation: I say to thee weapons reach not the Life; flame burns it not, waters cannot o'erwhelm, nor dry winds wither it.
verses.teaching: The soul cannot be cut by weapons, burned by fire, moistened by water, or dried by wind. It is beyond the reach of physical forces.

verses.sanskrit: अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च। नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः॥
verses.transliteration: acchedyo 'yam adāhyo 'yam akledyo 'śoṣya eva ca | nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇur acalo 'yaṁ sanātanaḥ ||
verses.translation: Impenetrable, unentered, unassailed, unharmed, untouched, immortal, all-arriving, stable, sure, invisible, ineffable, by word and thought uncompassed, ever all itself, thus is the Soul declared!
verses.teaching: The soul is uncleavable, incombustible, insoluble and unwitherable. It is eternal, omnipresent, unchangeable, immovable and eternally the same.

verses.sanskrit: अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते। तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि॥
verses.transliteration: avyakto 'yam acintyo 'yam avikāryo 'yam ucyate | tasmād evaṁ viditvainaṁ nānuśocitum arhasi ||
verses.translation: How wilt thou, then,—knowing it so,—grieve when thou shouldst not grieve?
verses.teaching: The soul is said to be unmanifest, unthinkable and unchangeable. Knowing this, you should not grieve for the temporary body.

verses.sanskrit: अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम्। तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
verses.transliteration: atha cainaṁ nitya-jātaṁ nityaṁ vā manyase mṛtam | tathāpi tvaṁ mahā-bāho naivaṁ śocitum arhasi ||
verses.translation: How, if thou hearest that the man new-dead is, like the man new-born, still living man—one same, existent Spirit—wilt thou weep?
verses.teaching: Even if you think the soul is perpetually taking birth and dying, still you should not grieve, O mighty-armed one, because this too is the natural way.

verses.sanskrit: जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च। तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
verses.transliteration: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṁ janma mṛtasya ca | tasmād aparihārye 'rthe na tvaṁ śocitum arhasi ||
verses.translation: The end of birth is death; the end of death is birth: this is ordained! and mournest thou, Chief of the stalwart arm! for what befalls which could not otherwise befall?
verses.teaching: For one who has taken birth, death is certain; and for one who is dead, birth is certain. Therefore, in the unavoidable discharge of duty, you should not lament.

verses.sanskrit: अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत। अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना॥
verses.transliteration: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyakta-madhyāni bhārata | avyakta-nidhanāny eva tatra kā paridevanā ||
verses.translation: The birth of living things comes unperceived; the death comes unperceived; between them, beings perceive: what is there sorrowful herein, dear Prince?
verses.teaching: All beings are unmanifest before birth, manifest between birth and death, and unmanifest again after death. So what is there to lament about?

verses.sanskrit: आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेनमाश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः। आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित्॥
verses.transliteration: āścarya-vat paśyati kaścid enam āścarya-vad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ | āścarya-vac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti śrutvāpy enaṁ veda na caiva kaścit ||
verses.translation: Wonderful, wistful, to contemplate! Difficult, doubtful, to speak upon! Strange and great for tongue to relate, mystical hearing for every one! Nor wotteth man this, what a marvel it is, when seeing, and saying, and hearing are done!
verses.teaching: Some look upon the soul as amazing, some speak of it as amazing, some hear of it as amazing, while others, even after hearing about it, cannot understand it at all.

verses.sanskrit: देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत। तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
verses.transliteration: dehī nityam avadhyo 'yaṁ dehe sarvasya bhārata | tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṁ śocitum arhasi ||
verses.translation: This Life within all living things, my Prince! hides beyond harm; scorn thou to suffer, then, for that which cannot suffer. Do thy part!
verses.teaching: The embodied soul in everyone's body is eternal and indestructible. Therefore, you should not grieve for any living being.

verses.sanskrit: स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि। धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते॥
verses.transliteration: sva-dharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi | dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyo 'nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate ||
verses.translation: Be mindful of thy name, and tremble not! Nought better can betide a martial soul than lawful war; happy the warrior to whom comes joy of battle—comes, as now, glorious and fair, unsought; opening for him a gateway unto Heav'n.
verses.teaching: Considering your specific duty as a warrior, you should not waver. For a warrior, there is no better engagement than fighting for righteousness.

verses.sanskrit: यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम्। सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम्॥
verses.transliteration: yadṛcchayā copapannaṁ svarga-dvāram apāvṛtam | sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam ||
verses.translation: But, if thou shunn'st this honourable field—a Kshattriya—if, knowing thy duty and thy task, thou bidd'st duty and task go by—that shall be sin!
verses.teaching: O Partha, happy are the warriors who obtain such a battle, which comes of its own accord as an open door to heaven.

verses.sanskrit: अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि। ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि॥
verses.transliteration: atha cet tvam imaṁ dharmyaṁ saṅgrāmaṁ na kariṣyasi | tataḥ sva-dharmaṁ kīrtiṁ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi ||
verses.translation: And those to come shall speak thee infamy from age to age; but infamy is worse for men of noble blood to bear than death!
verses.teaching: If you do not engage in this righteous war, then you will certainly incur sin by neglecting your duties and losing your reputation.

verses.sanskrit: अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम्। सम्भावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: akīrtiṁ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te 'vyayām | sambhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate ||
verses.translation: The chiefs upon their battle-chariots will deem 'twas fear that drove thee from the fray. Of those who held thee mighty-souled the scorn thou must abide, while all thine enemies will scatter bitter speech of thee, to mock the valour which thou hadst; what fate could fall more grievously than this?
verses.teaching: People will always speak of your infamy, and for a respectable person, dishonor is worse than death.

verses.sanskrit: भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः। येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम्॥
verses.transliteration: bhayād raṇād uparataṁ maṁsyante tvāṁ mahā-rathāḥ | yeṣāṁ ca tvaṁ bahu-mato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam ||
verses.translation: Either—being killed—thou wilt win Swarga's safety, or—alive and victor—thou wilt reign an earthly king. Therefore, arise, thou Son of Kunti! brace thine arm for conflict, nerve thy heart to meet—as things alike to thee—pleasure or pain, profit or ruin, victory or defeat: so minded, gird thee to the fight, for so thou shalt not sin!
verses.teaching: The great generals will think that you have withdrawn from the battlefield out of fear. Those who have held you in great esteem will fall down in their estimation of you.

verses.sanskrit: अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः। निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम्॥
verses.transliteration: avācya-vādāṁś ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ | nindantas tava sāmarthyaṁ tato duḥkhataraṁ nu kim ||
verses.translation: Your enemies will speak many unkind words and scorn your ability. What could be more painful than this?
verses.teaching: Your enemies will speak many harsh words and criticize your abilities. What could be more painful than this humiliation?

verses.sanskrit: हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम्। तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः॥
verses.transliteration: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṁ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm | tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛta-niścayaḥ ||
verses.translation: O son of Kunti, either you will be killed on the battlefield and attain the heavenly planets, or you will conquer and enjoy the earthly kingdom. Therefore, get up with determination and fight.
verses.teaching: There are only two outcomes in righteous battle: victory leads to earthly enjoyment, death leads to heavenly reward. Both outcomes are favorable for a warrior doing his duty.

verses.sanskrit: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ। ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि॥
verses.transliteration: sukha-duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṁ pāpam avāpsyasi ||
verses.translation: So minded, gird thee to the fight, for so thou shalt not sin! Thus far I speak to thee as from the 'Sankhya'—unspiritually—hear now the deeper teaching of the Yog, which holding, understanding, thou shalt burst thy Karmabandh, the bondage of wrought deeds.
verses.teaching: Treating pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat equally, engage in battle. In this way you will never incur sin.

verses.sanskrit: एषा तेऽभिहिता सांख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु। बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि॥
verses.transliteration: eṣā te 'bhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṁ śṛṇu | buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karma-bandhaṁ prahāsyasi ||
verses.translation: Thus far I have taught you analytical knowledge. Now listen as I explain it in terms of working without fruitive results. O son of Pritha, when you act with such intelligence you can free yourself from the bondage of works.
verses.teaching: So far this wisdom has been presented through analytical study. Now hear about it in terms of yoga. By this understanding, you can break free from the bondage of action.

verses.sanskrit: नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते। स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात्॥
verses.transliteration: nehābhikrama-nāśo 'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpam apy asya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt ||
verses.translation: Here shall no end be hindered, no hope marred, no loss be feared: faith—yea, a little faith—shall save thee from the anguish of thy dread.
verses.teaching: In this endeavor there is no loss or diminution, and a little advancement on this path can protect one from the most dangerous type of fear.

verses.sanskrit: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन। बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम्॥
verses.transliteration: vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kuru-nandana | bahu-śākhā hy anantāś ca buddhayo 'vyavasāyinām ||
verses.translation: Here, Glory of the Kurus! shines one rule—one steadfast rule—while shifting souls have laws many and hard.
verses.teaching: Those who are on this path are resolute in purpose, and their aim is one. O beloved child of the Kurus, the intelligence of the irresolute is many-branched.

verses.sanskrit: यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः। वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः॥
verses.transliteration: yām imāṁ puṣpitāṁ vācaṁ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ | veda-vāda-ratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādinaḥ ||
verses.translation: Specious, but wrongful deem the speech of those ill-taught ones who extol the letter of their Vedas, saying, 'This is all we have, or need;' being weak at heart with wants, seekers of Heaven.
verses.teaching: Men of small knowledge are very much attached to the flowery words of the Vedas, which recommend various fruitive activities for elevation to heavenly planets.

verses.sanskrit: कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम्। क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति॥
verses.transliteration: kāmātmānaḥ svarga-parā janma-karma-phala-pradām | kriyā-viśeṣa-bahulāṁ bhogaiśvarya-gatiṁ prati ||
verses.translation: Which comes—they say—as 'fruit of good deeds done;' promising men much profit in new births for works of faith; in various rites abounding.
verses.teaching: Driven by desire and aimed at heaven, they speak flowery words that promise new birth as the reward of their actions, prescribing various elaborate rituals for the attainment of pleasure and power.

verses.sanskrit: भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम्। व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते॥
verses.transliteration: bhogaiśvarya-prasaktānāṁ tayāpahṛta-cetasām | vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate ||
verses.translation: Albeit, who wealth and power do most desire least fixity of soul have such, least hold on heavenly meditation.
verses.teaching: In the minds of those who are too attached to sense enjoyment and material opulence, and who are bewildered by such things, the resolute determination for devotional service does not take place.

verses.sanskrit: त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन। निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान्॥
verses.transliteration: traiguṇya-viṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna | nirdvandvo nitya-sattva-stho niryoga-kṣema ātmavān ||
verses.translation: Much these teach, from Veds, concerning the 'three qualities;' but thou, be free of the 'three qualities,' free of the 'pairs of opposites,' and free from that sad righteousness which calculates; self-ruled, Arjuna! simple, satisfied!
verses.teaching: The Vedas deal mainly with the subject of the three modes of material nature. O Arjuna, become transcendental to these three modes. Be free from all dualities and from all anxieties for gain and safety, and be established in the self.

verses.sanskrit: यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः सम्प्लुतोदके। तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः॥
verses.transliteration: yāvān artha udapāne sarvataḥ samplutodake | tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ ||
verses.translation: Look! like as when a tank pours water forth to suit all needs, so do these Brahmans draw text for all wants from tank of Holy Writ. But thou, want not! ask not! Find full reward of doing right in right!
verses.teaching: All purposes served by a small well can at once be served by a great reservoir of water. Similarly, all the purposes of the Vedas can be served to one who knows the purpose behind them.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन। मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि॥
verses.transliteration: karmaṇy evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo 'stv akarmaṇi ||
verses.translation: Let right deeds be thy motive, not the fruit which comes from them. And live in action! Labour! Make thine acts thy piety, casting all self aside, contemning gain and merit; equable in good or evil: equability is Yog, is piety!
verses.teaching: You have a right to perform your prescribed duty, but not to the fruits of action. Never consider yourself the cause of the results of your activities, and never be attached to not doing your duty.

verses.sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yoga-sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya | siddhy-asiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṁ yoga ucyate ||
verses.translation: Yet, the right act is less, far less, than the right-thinking mind. Seek refuge in thy soul; have there thy heaven! Scorn them that follow virtue for her gifts!
verses.teaching: Perform your duty equipoised, O Arjuna, abandoning all attachment to success or failure. Such equanimity is called yoga.

verses.sanskrit: दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय। बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः॥
verses.transliteration: dūreṇa hy avaraṁ karma buddhi-yogād dhanañjaya | buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phala-hetavaḥ ||
verses.translation: Far lower than the right-thinking mind is mere right action, O Dhananjaya. Seek refuge in the attitude of wisdom. Those who work for reward are wretched.
verses.teaching: O Dhananjaya, keep all abominable activities far distant by devotional service, and in that consciousness surrender unto the Lord. Those who want to enjoy the fruits of their work are misers.

verses.sanskrit: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते। तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम्॥
verses.transliteration: buddhi-yukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛta-duṣkṛte | tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam ||
verses.translation: The mind of pure devotion—even here—casts equally aside good deeds and bad, passing above them. Unto pure devotion devote thyself: with perfect meditation comes perfect act.
verses.teaching: A man engaged in devotional service rids himself of both good and bad actions even in this life. Therefore strive for yoga, which is the art of all work.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः। जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम्॥
verses.transliteration: karma-jaṁ buddhi-yuktā hi phalaṁ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ | janma-bandha-vinirmuktāḥ padaṁ gacchanty anāmayam ||
verses.translation: When thy firm soul hath shaken off those tangled oracles which ignorantly guide, then shall it soar to high neglect of what's denied or said, this way or that way, in doctrinal writ.
verses.teaching: By thus engaging in devotional service to the Lord, great sages or devotees free themselves from the results of work in the material world. In this way they become free from the cycle of birth and death and attain the state beyond all miseries.

verses.sanskrit: यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति। तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च॥
verses.transliteration: yadā te moha-kalilaṁ buddhir vyatitariṣyati | tadā gantāsi nirvedaṁ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca ||
verses.translation: Troubled no longer by the priestly lore, safe shall it live, and sure; steadfastly bent on meditation. This is Yog—and Peace!
verses.teaching: When your intelligence has passed out of the dense forest of delusion, you shall become indifferent to all that has been heard and all that is to be heard.

verses.sanskrit: श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला। समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि॥
verses.transliteration: śruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā | samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi ||
verses.translation: When your mind is no longer disturbed by the flowery language of the Vedas, and when it remains fixed in the trance of self-realization, then you will have attained the divine consciousness.
verses.teaching: When your mind is no longer disturbed by the flowery language of the Vedas, and when it remains fixed in the trance of self-realization, then you will have attained the Divine consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव। स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम्॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi-sthasya keśava | sthita-dhīḥ kiṁ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim ||
verses.translation: What is his mark who hath that steadfast heart, confirmed in holy meditation? How know we his speech, Kesava? Sits he, moves he like other men?
verses.teaching: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what are the symptoms of one whose consciousness is thus merged in transcendence? How does he speak, and what is his language? How does he sit, and how does he walk?

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान्। आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha mano-gatān | ātmany evātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita-prajñas tadocyate ||
verses.translation: When one, O Pritha's Son! abandoning desires which shake the mind—finds in his soul full comfort for his soul, he hath attained the Yog—that man is such!
verses.teaching: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: O Partha, when a man gives up all varieties of desire for sense gratification, which arise from mental concoction, and when his mind, thus purified, finds satisfaction in the self alone, then he is said to be in pure transcendental consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः। वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: duḥkheṣv anudvigna-manāḥ sukheṣu vigata-spṛhaḥ | vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir ucyate ||
verses.translation: In sorrows not dejected, and in joys not overjoyed; dwelling outside the stress of passion, fear, and anger; fixed in calms of lofty contemplation;—such an one is Muni, is the Sage, the true Recluse!
verses.teaching: One who is not disturbed in mind even amidst the threefold miseries or elated when there is happiness, and who is free from attachment, fear and anger, is called a sage of steady mind.

verses.sanskrit: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्। नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
verses.transliteration: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tat tat prāpya śubhāśubham | nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||
verses.translation: He who to none and nowhere overbound by ties of flesh, takes evil things and good neither desponding nor exulting, such bears wisdom's plainest mark!
verses.teaching: In the material world, one who is unattached to the fruits of his work and who acts as a matter of duty is in the renounced order of life, and he is the true mystic.

verses.sanskrit: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
verses.transliteration: yadā saṁharate cāyaṁ kūrmo 'ṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ | indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||
verses.translation: He who shall draw as the wise tortoise draws its four feet safe under its shield, his five frail senses back under the spirit's buckler from the world which else assails them, such an one, my Prince! hath wisdom's mark!
verses.teaching: One who is able to withdraw his senses from sense objects, as the tortoise draws its limbs within the shell, is firmly fixed in perfect consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः। रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते॥
verses.transliteration: viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ | rasa-varjaṁ raso 'py asya paraṁ dṛṣṭvā nivartate ||
verses.translation: Things that solicit sense hold off from the self-governed; nay, it comes, the appetites of him who lives beyond depart,—aroused no more.
verses.teaching: Though the embodied soul may be restricted from sense enjoyment, the taste for sense objects remains. But, ceasing such engagements by experiencing a higher taste, he is fixed in consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः। इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः॥
verses.transliteration: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ | indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṁ manaḥ ||
verses.translation: Yet may it chance, O Son of Kunti! that a governed mind shall some time feel the sense-storms sweep, and wrest strong self-control by the roots.
verses.teaching: The senses are so strong and impetuous, O Arjuna, that they forcibly carry away the mind even of a man of discrimination who is endeavoring to control them.

verses.sanskrit: तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः। वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
verses.transliteration: tāni sarvāṇi saṁyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ | vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||
verses.translation: Let him regain his kingdom! let him conquer this, and sit on Me intent. That man alone is wise who keeps the mastery of himself!
verses.teaching: One who restrains his senses, keeping them under full control, and fixes his consciousness upon Me, is known as a man of steady intelligence.

verses.sanskrit: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते। सङ्गात्संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते॥
verses.transliteration: dhyāyato viṣayān puṁsaḥ saṅgas teṣūpajāyate | saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodho 'bhijāyate ||
verses.translation: If one ponders on objects of the sense, there springs attraction; from attraction grows desire, desire flames to fierce passion, passion breeds recklessness.
verses.teaching: While contemplating the objects of the senses, a person develops attachment for them, and from such attachment lust develops, and from lust anger arises.

verses.sanskrit: क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः। स्मृतिभ्रंशाद्बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति॥
verses.transliteration: krodhād bhavati sammohaḥ sammohāt smṛti-vibhramaḥ | smṛti-bhraṁśād buddhi-nāśo buddhi-nāśāt praṇaśyati ||
verses.translation: Then the memory—all betrayed—lets noble purpose go, and saps the mind, till purpose, mind, and man are all undone.
verses.teaching: From anger, complete delusion arises, and from delusion bewilderment of memory. When memory is bewildered, intelligence is lost, and when intelligence is lost one falls down again into the material pool.

verses.sanskrit: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्। आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: rāga-dveṣa-viyuktais tu viṣayān indriyaiś caran | ātma-vaśyair vidheyātmā prasādam adhigacchati ||
verses.translation: But, if one deals with objects of the sense not loving and not hating, making them serve his free soul, which rests serenely lord, Lo! such a man comes to tranquillity.
verses.teaching: But a person free from all attachment and aversion and able to control his senses through regulative principles of freedom can obtain the complete mercy of the Lord.

verses.sanskrit: प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते। प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते॥
verses.transliteration: prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir asyopajāyate | prasanna-cetaso hy āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate ||
verses.translation: And out of that tranquillity shall rise the end and healing of his earthly pains, since the will governed sets the soul at peace.
verses.teaching: For one thus satisfied by mercy, all kinds of mental disturbances are destroyed. On such a satisfied person, intelligence is soon well established.

verses.sanskrit: नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना। न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम्॥
verses.transliteration: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā | na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham ||
verses.translation: The soul of the ungoverned is not his, nor hath he knowledge of himself; which lacked, how grows serenity? and, wanting that, whence shall he hope for happiness?
verses.teaching: One who is not connected with the Supreme can have neither transcendental intelligence nor a steady mind, without which there is no possibility of peace. And how can there be any happiness without peace?

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते। तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि॥
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇāṁ hi caratāṁ yan mano 'nuvidhīyate | tad asya harati prajñāṁ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi ||
verses.translation: The mind that gives itself to follow shows of sense seeth its helm of wisdom rent away, and, like a ship in waves of whirlwind, drives to wreck and death.
verses.teaching: As a strong wind sweeps away a boat on the water, even one of the roaming senses on which the mind focuses can carry away a man's intelligence.

verses.sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
verses.transliteration: tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ | indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||
verses.translation: Only with him, great Prince! whose senses are not swayed by things of sense—only with him who holds his mastery, shows wisdom perfect.
verses.teaching: Therefore, O mighty-armed, one whose senses are restrained from their objects is firmly fixed in perfect consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी। यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः॥
verses.transliteration: yā niśā sarva-bhūtānāṁ tasyāṁ jāgarti saṁyamī | yasyāṁ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ ||
verses.translation: What is midnight-gloom to unenlightened souls shines wakeful day to his clear gaze; what seems as wakeful day is known for night, thick night of ignorance, to his true-seeing eyes. Such is the Saint!
verses.teaching: What is night for all beings is the time of awakening for the self-controlled; and the time of awakening for all beings is night for the introspective sage.

verses.sanskrit: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्। तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी॥
verses.transliteration: āpūryamāṇam acala-pratiṣṭhaṁ samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat | tadvat kāmā yaṁ praviśanti sarve sa śāntim āpnoti na kāma-kāmī ||
verses.translation: And like the ocean, day by day receiving floods from all lands, which never overflows its boundary-line not leaping, and not leaving, fed by the rivers, but unswelled by those;—so is the perfect one! to his soul's ocean the world of sense pours streams of witchery; they leave him as they find, without commotion, taking their tribute, but remaining sea.
verses.teaching: A person who is not disturbed by the incessant flow of desires—that enter like rivers into the ocean, which is ever being filled but is always still—can alone achieve peace, and not the man who strives to satisfy such desires.

verses.sanskrit: विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः। निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṁś carati niḥspṛhaḥ | nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchati ||
verses.translation: Yea! whoso, shaking off the yoke of flesh lives lord, not servant, of his lusts; set free from pride, from passion, from the sin of 'Self,' toucheth tranquillity!
verses.teaching: A person who has given up all desires for sense gratification, who lives free from desires, who has given up all sense of proprietorship and is devoid of false ego—he alone can attain real peace.

verses.sanskrit: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति। स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṁ prāpya vimuhyati | sthitvāsyām anta-kāle 'pi brahma-nirvāṇam ṛcchati ||
verses.translation: O Pritha's Son! That is the state of Brahm! There rests no dread when that last step is reached! Live where he will, die when he may, such passeth from all 'plaining, to blest Nirvana, with the Gods, attaining.
verses.teaching: That is the way of the spiritual and godly life, O son of Pritha. After attaining this, a person is not bewildered. Being so situated even at the hour of death, one can enter into the kingdom of God.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन। तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca jyāyasī cet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana | tat kiṁ karmaṇi ghore māṁ niyojayasi keśava ||
verses.translation: Thou whom all mortals praise, Janardana! If meditation be a nobler thing than action, wherefore, then, great Kesava! Dost thou impel me to this dreadful fight?
verses.teaching: Arjuna is confused by what seems like contradictory advice - Krishna praised wisdom but is asking him to fight. This confusion arises when we don't understand how knowledge and action work together.

verses.sanskrit: व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे। तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम्॥
verses.transliteration: vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṁ mohayasīva me | tad ekaṁ vada niścitya yena śreyo 'ham āpnuyām ||
verses.translation: Now am I by thy doubtful speech disturbed! Tell me one thing, and tell me certainly; by what road shall I find the better end?
verses.teaching: When faced with apparent contradictions in spiritual teaching, we should seek clarity through sincere inquiry rather than remaining confused. A good student asks for definitive guidance.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ। ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम्॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca loke 'smin dvi-vidhā niṣṭhā purā proktā mayānagha | jñāna-yogena sāṅkhyānāṁ karma-yogena yoginām ||
verses.translation: I told thee, blameless Lord! there be two paths shown to this world; two schools of wisdom. First the Sankhya's, which doth save in way of works prescribed by reason; next, the Yog, which bids attain by meditation, spiritually.
verses.teaching: Krishna clarifies that there are two valid spiritual paths: the path of knowledge (jnana-yoga) for contemplatives, and the path of action (karma-yoga) for those engaged in the world. Both lead to the same goal.

verses.sanskrit: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते। न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣkarmyaṁ puruṣo 'śnute | na ca sannyasanād eva siddhiṁ samadhigacchati ||
verses.translation: Yet these are one! No man shall 'scape from act by shunning action; nay, and none shall come by mere renouncements unto perfectness.
verses.teaching: Simply avoiding action doesn't lead to freedom from action's bondage, nor does external renunciation alone bring spiritual perfection. True freedom comes from right understanding and right action.

verses.sanskrit: न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्। कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः॥
verses.transliteration: na hi kaścit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhaty akarma-kṛt | kāryate hy avaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ ||
verses.translation: Nay, and no jot of time, at any time, rests any actionless; his nature's law compels him, even unwilling, into act.
verses.teaching: Complete inaction is impossible - everyone is constantly compelled to act by the forces of material nature. Even breathing, thinking, and bodily functions are actions. The goal is right action, not no action.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्। इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते॥
verses.transliteration: karmendriyāṇi saṁyamya ya āste manasā smaran | indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā mithyācāraḥ sa ucyate ||
verses.translation: For thought is act in fancy. He who sits suppressing all the instruments of flesh, yet in his idle heart thinking on them, plays the inept and guilty hypocrite.
verses.teaching: A person who restrains the senses externally but mentally dwells on sense objects is a hypocrite. True renunciation involves both external control and internal purity of thought.

verses.sanskrit: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन। कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yas tv indriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate 'rjuna | karmendriyaiḥ karma-yogam asaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate ||
verses.translation: But he who, with strong body serving mind, gives up his mortal powers to worthy work, not seeking gain, Arjuna! such an one is honourable.
verses.teaching: Superior is the person who controls the senses with the mind and engages in karma-yoga with the working senses, without attachment. This integration of inner control with outer service is the ideal.

verses.sanskrit: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः। शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः॥
verses.transliteration: niyataṁ kuru karma tvaṁ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ | śarīra-yātrāpi ca te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ ||
verses.translation: Do thine allotted task! Work is more excellent than idleness; the body's life proceeds not, lacking work.
verses.teaching: Perform your prescribed duties, for action is better than inaction. Even maintaining your body would be impossible without work. Purposeful action is necessary for both material and spiritual life.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः। तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर॥
verses.transliteration: yajñārthāt karmaṇo 'nyatra loko 'yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ | tad-arthaṁ karma kaunteya mukta-saṅgaḥ samācara ||
verses.translation: There is a task of holiness to do, unlike world-binding toil, which bindeth not the faithful soul; such earthly duty do free from desire, and thou shalt well perform thy heavenly purpose.
verses.teaching: Work performed as sacrifice (yajna) liberates, while work done for personal gain binds us. When we dedicate our actions to a higher purpose, work becomes a spiritual practice rather than bondage.

verses.sanskrit: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः। अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक्॥
verses.transliteration: saha-yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā purovāca prajāpatiḥ | anena prasaviṣyadhvam eṣa vo 'stv iṣṭa-kāma-dhuk ||
verses.translation: Spake Prajapati—in the beginning, when all men were made, and, with mankind, the sacrifice—'Do this! Work! sacrifice! Increase and multiply with sacrifice! This shall be Kamaduk, your 'Cow of Plenty,' giving back her milk of all abundance.'
verses.teaching: The creator established sacrifice as the principle of cosmic harmony. When we live in the spirit of giving and service rather than taking and exploitation, abundance flows naturally.

verses.sanskrit: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः। परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ॥
verses.transliteration: devān bhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ | parasparaṁ bhāvayantaḥ śreyaḥ param avāpsyatha ||
verses.translation: Worship the gods thereby; the gods shall yield thee grace. Those meats ye crave the gods will grant to Labour, when it pays tithes in the altar-flame.
verses.teaching: Through sacrifice, we nourish the cosmic forces (devas) that sustain life, and they in turn provide for our needs. This mutual nourishment creates harmony between humanity and nature.

verses.sanskrit: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः। तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः॥
verses.transliteration: iṣṭān bhogān hi vo devā dāsyante yajña-bhāvitāḥ | tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ ||
verses.translation: But if one eats fruits of the earth, rendering to kindly Heaven no gift of toil, that thief steals from his world.
verses.teaching: Those who enjoy the gifts of nature and society without giving back in service are essentially thieves. True prosperity comes from contributing to the welfare of all, not just consuming.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः। भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात्॥
verses.transliteration: yajña-śiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarva-kilbiṣaiḥ | bhuñjate te tv aghaṁ pāpā ye pacanty ātma-kāraṇāt ||
verses.translation: Who eat of food after their sacrifice are quit of fault, but they that spread a feast all for themselves, eat sin and drink of sin.
verses.teaching: The righteous who eat the remnants of sacrifice are freed from all sins, but the selfish who cook only for themselves eat sin. Sharing and gratitude purify our enjoyment of life's gifts.

verses.sanskrit: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः। यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः॥
verses.transliteration: annād bhavanti bhūtāni parjanyād anna-sambhavaḥ | yajñād bhavati parjanyo yajñaḥ karma-samudbhavaḥ ||
verses.translation: By food the living live; food comes of rain, and rain comes by the pious sacrifice, and sacrifice is paid with tithes of toil.
verses.teaching: Krishna explains the cosmic cycle: beings depend on food, food comes from rain, rain from sacrifice, sacrifice from action. This shows how all life is interconnected through cycles of giving and receiving.

verses.sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्। तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
verses.transliteration: karma brahmodbhavaṁ viddhi brahmākṣara-samudbhavam | tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam ||
verses.translation: Thus action is of Brahma, who is One, the Only, All-pervading; at all times present in sacrifice.
verses.teaching: Action originates from Brahma (the Vedas/Divine), which comes from the imperishable Supreme. Therefore, the all-pervading Brahman is always present in sacrifice, making all righteous action sacred.

verses.sanskrit: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः। अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ pravartitaṁ cakraṁ nānuvartayatīha yaḥ | aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṁ pārtha sa jīvati ||
verses.translation: He that abstains to help the rolling wheels of this great world, glutting his idle sense, lives a lost life, shameful and vain. Existing for himself, self-concentrated, serving self alone, no part hath he in aught; nothing achieved, nought wrought or unwrought toucheth him; no hope of help for all the living things of earth depends from him.
verses.teaching: One who does not follow this cycle of sacrifice, who lives only for sensory pleasure, lives uselessly. Such a life is wasted because it contributes nothing to the cosmic order or the welfare of others.

verses.sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः। आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते॥
verses.transliteration: yas tv ātma-ratir eva syād ātma-tṛptaś ca mānavaḥ | ātmany eva ca santuṣṭas tasya kāryaṁ na vidyate ||
verses.translation: Therefore, thy task prescribed with spirit unattached gladly perform, since in performance of plain duty man mounts to his highest bliss.
verses.teaching: However, for one who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied in the Self, and who is content in the Self alone - for such a person there is no duty. They have transcended obligatory action through self-realization.

verses.sanskrit: नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन। न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः॥
verses.transliteration: naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nākṛteneha kaścana | na cāsya sarva-bhūteṣu kaścid artha-vyapāśrayaḥ ||
verses.translation: By works alone Janak and ancient saints reached blessedness! Moreover, for the upholding of thy kind, action thou should'st embrace.
verses.teaching: A self-realized person has nothing to gain from action or inaction in this world, and has no need to depend on any being. Yet even such beings may act for the welfare of the world.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर। असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः॥
verses.transliteration: tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samācara | asakto hy ācaran karma param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ ||
verses.translation: What the wise choose the unwise people take; what best men do the multitude will follow.
verses.teaching: Therefore, always perform your duty efficiently and without attachment. By working without attachment one attains the Supreme. This is the path for those still progressing spiritually.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः। लोकसंग्रहमेवापि सम्पश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि॥
verses.transliteration: karmaṇaiva hi saṁsiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ | loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśyan kartum arhasi ||
verses.translation: By works alone Janak and ancient saints reached blessedness! Moreover, for the upholding of thy kind, action thou should'st embrace.
verses.teaching: King Janaka and other enlightened rulers attained perfection through action. Even considering the welfare of the world, you should perform your duty. Great souls act as examples for others.

verses.sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः। स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते॥
verses.transliteration: yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ | sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate ||
verses.translation: What the wise choose the unwise people take; what best men do the multitude will follow.
verses.teaching: Whatever action a great person performs, common people follow. Whatever standards they set by exemplary acts, the world pursues. Leaders have a responsibility to set the right example.

verses.sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन। नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि॥
verses.transliteration: na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣu lokeṣu kiñcana | nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva ca karmaṇi ||
verses.translation: Look on me, thou Son of Pritha! in the three wide worlds I am not bound to any toil, no height awaits to scale, no gift remains to gain, yet I act here!
verses.teaching: Krishna personally has nothing to gain in all three worlds, yet He continues to act. This demonstrates that enlightened action is not motivated by personal need but by universal welfare.

verses.sanskrit: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
verses.transliteration: yadi hy ahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ | mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ ||
verses.translation: And, if I acted not—earnest and watchful—those that look to me for guidance, sinking back to sloth again because I slumbered, would decline from good, and I should break earth's order and commit her offspring unto ruin, Bharata!
verses.teaching: If Krishna did not engage in action, people would follow His example and neglect their duties, leading to societal chaos. This shows the responsibility of those who serve as role models.

verses.sanskrit: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्। सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः॥
verses.transliteration: utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ced aham | saṅkarasya ca kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ ||
verses.translation: Even as the unknowing toil, wedded to sense, so let the enlightened toil, sense-freed, but set to bring the world deliverance, and its bliss; not sowing in those simple, busy hearts seed of despair.
verses.teaching: If Krishna ceased to work, the worlds would perish. He would be the cause of confusion and would destroy all these people. Even the enlightened must act to maintain cosmic and social order.

verses.sanskrit: सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत। कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम्॥
verses.transliteration: saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvāṁso yathā kurvanti bhārata | kuryād vidvāṁs tathāsaktaś cikīrṣur loka-saṅgraham ||
verses.translation: Yea! let each play his part in all he finds to do, with unyoked soul. All things are everywhere by Nature wrought in interaction of the qualities.
verses.teaching: As the ignorant act with attachment to their work, the wise should act without attachment, desiring to lead people on the right path. The wise work for the welfare of the world.

verses.sanskrit: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्। जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्तः समाचरन्॥
verses.transliteration: na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām | joṣayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācaran ||
verses.translation: The fool, cheated by self, thinks, 'This I did' and 'That I wrought;' but—ah, thou strong-armed Prince!—a better-lessoned mind, knowing the play of visible things within the world of sense, and how the qualities must qualify, standeth aloof even from his acts.
verses.teaching: The wise should not unsettle the minds of the ignorant who are attached to action. Instead, they should engage them in all activities while themselves acting with devotion and proper understanding.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः। अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते॥
verses.transliteration: prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ | ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate ||
verses.translation: All things are everywhere by Nature wrought in interaction of the qualities. The fool, cheated by self, thinks, 'This I did' and 'That I wrought.'
verses.teaching: All actions are performed by the modes of material nature, but one deluded by false ego thinks 'I am the doer.' Understanding that nature acts while the Self observes brings freedom.

verses.sanskrit: तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः। गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते॥
verses.transliteration: tattva-vit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ | guṇā guṇeṣu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate ||
verses.translation: But, ah, thou strong-armed Prince!—a better-lessoned mind, knowing the play of visible things within the world of sense, and how the qualities must qualify, standeth aloof even from his acts.
verses.teaching: One who knows the truth about the divisions of the modes and actions understands that it is the modes acting upon modes. Such a person does not become attached, seeing the Self as separate from action.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु। तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्॥
verses.transliteration: prakṛter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu | tān akṛtsna-vido mandān kṛtsna-vin na vicālayet ||
verses.translation: Th' untaught live mixed with them, knowing not Nature's way, of highest aims unwitting, slow and dull. Those make thou not to stumble, having the light.
verses.teaching: Those deluded by the modes of nature become attached to the activities of the modes. The wise should not disturb the minds of the ignorant who have incomplete knowledge, but should engage them gradually.

verses.sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा। निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः॥
verses.transliteration: mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasyādhyātma-cetasā | nirāśīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ ||
verses.translation: But all thy dues discharging, for My sake, with meditation centred inwardly, seeking no profit, satisfied, serene, heedless of issue—fight!
verses.teaching: Surrendering all actions to Me with full consciousness of the Self, being free from desire and possessiveness, and cured of mental fever - fight! This is the essence of karma-yoga: dedicated action without attachment.

verses.sanskrit: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः॥
verses.transliteration: ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ | śraddhāvanto 'nasūyanto mucyante te 'pi karmabhiḥ ||
verses.translation: They who shall keep my ordinance thus, the wise and willing hearts, have quittance from all issue of their acts.
verses.teaching: Those who regularly follow this teaching of Mine with faith and without envy are freed from the bondage of actions. Simple faith and sincere practice lead to liberation.

verses.sanskrit: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्। सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः॥
verses.transliteration: ye tv etad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam | sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāṁs tān viddhi naṣṭān acetasaḥ ||
verses.translation: But those who disregard My ordinance, thinking they know, know nought, and fall to loss, confused and foolish.
verses.teaching: But those who find fault with My teaching and do not practice it are deluded in all knowledge, devoid of discrimination, and doomed to ignorance and bondage. Criticism without practice leads nowhere.

verses.sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि। प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति॥
verses.transliteration: sadṛśaṁ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛter jñānavān api | prakṛtiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣyati ||
verses.translation: 'Sooth, the instructed one doth of his kind, following what fits him most: and lower creatures of their kind; in vain contending 'gainst the law.
verses.teaching: Even the wise act according to their nature; all beings follow their nature. What can mere repression accomplish? We must work with our nature, refining it through practice rather than fighting against it.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ। तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ॥
verses.transliteration: indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāga-dveṣau vyavasthitau | tayor na vaśam āgacchet tau hy asya paripanthinau ||
verses.translation: Needs must it be the objects of the sense will stir the sense to like and dislike, yet th' enlightened man yields not to these, knowing them enemies.
verses.teaching: Attraction and aversion for sense objects are natural, but one should not come under their control, for they are obstacles on the path. We must acknowledge these tendencies while not being controlled by them.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः॥
verses.transliteration: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt | sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ ||
verses.translation: Finally, this is better, that one do his own task as he may, even though he fail, than take tasks not his own, though they seem good. To die performing duty is no ill; but who seeks other roads shall wander still.
verses.teaching: It is better to perform one's own duty imperfectly than to perform another's duty perfectly. Even death in one's own duty is preferable; another's duty brings danger. Each person has their unique path.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः। अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः॥
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca atha kena prayukto 'yaṁ pāpaṁ carati pūruṣaḥ | anicchann api vārṣṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ ||
verses.translation: Yet tell me, Teacher! by what force doth man go to his ill, unwilling; as if one pushed him that evil path?
verses.teaching: Arjuna asks the crucial question: What compels a person to commit sin even against their will, as if forced? This shows the recognition that we often act against our better judgment.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः। महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्॥
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ | mahāśano mahā-pāpmā viddhy enam iha vairiṇam ||
verses.translation: Kama it is! Passion it is! born of the Darknesses, which pusheth him. Mighty of appetite, sinful, and strong is this!—man's enemy!
verses.teaching: The Supreme Lord said: It is lust and anger, born from the mode of passion, which are all-devouring and greatly sinful. Know this to be the enemy. Desire transforms into anger when frustrated.

verses.sanskrit: धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च। यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्॥
verses.transliteration: dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśo malena ca | yatholbenāvṛto garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛtam ||
verses.translation: As smoke blots the white fire, as clinging rust mars the bright mirror, as the womb surrounds the babe unborn, so is the world of things foiled, soiled, enclosed in this desire of flesh.
verses.teaching: As fire is covered by smoke, a mirror by dust, and an embryo by the womb, so is knowledge covered by desire. These analogies show different degrees of obscuration - some easier to remove than others.

verses.sanskrit: आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा। कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च॥
verses.transliteration: āvṛtaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā | kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇānalena ca ||
verses.translation: The wise fall, caught in it; the unresting foe it is of wisdom, wearing countless forms, fair but deceitful, subtle as a flame.
verses.teaching: O son of Kunti, knowledge is covered by this eternal enemy in the form of insatiable desire, which is like fire. Desire can never be fully satisfied and always seeks more fuel.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते। एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्॥
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣṭhānam ucyate | etair vimohayaty eṣa jñānam āvṛtya dehinam ||
verses.translation: Sense, mind, and reason—these, O Kunti's Son! are booty for it; in its play with these it maddens man, beguiling, blinding him.
verses.teaching: The senses, mind, and intelligence are said to be the seats of desire. Through these, desire covers knowledge and deludes the embodied soul. Understanding where desire operates helps us combat it.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ। पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्॥
verses.transliteration: tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣabha | pāpmānaṁ prajahi hy enaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśanam ||
verses.translation: Therefore, thou noblest child of Bharata! govern thy heart! Constrain th' entangled sense! Resist the false, soft sinfulness which saps knowledge and judgment!
verses.teaching: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, control your senses from the very beginning and slay this sinful enemy which destroys both knowledge and realization. Self-control is the first step to victory over desire.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः। मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः॥
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ | manasas tu parā buddhir yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ ||
verses.translation: Yea, the world is strong, but what discerns it stronger, and the mind strongest; and high o'er all the ruling Soul.
verses.teaching: The senses are said to be superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intelligence is superior to the mind; and the soul is superior to the intelligence. Understanding this hierarchy helps us gain mastery.

verses.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना। जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम्॥
verses.transliteration: evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā saṁstabhyātmānam ātmanā | jahi śatruṁ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam ||
verses.translation: Wherefore, perceiving Him who reigns supreme, put forth full force of Soul in thy own soul! Fight! vanquish foes and doubts, dear Hero! slay what haunts thee in fond shapes, and would betray!
verses.teaching: Thus knowing the soul to be superior to the intelligence, O mighty-armed, stabilize the self by the self and conquer this formidable enemy in the form of desire. Use your higher nature to control your lower nature.

verses.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
verses.transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata | abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmy aham ||
verses.translation: Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness increases, O Arjuna, at that time I manifest myself on earth.
verses.teaching: Divine intervention occurs when righteousness is threatened. This speaks to the cyclical nature of cosmic balance and hope in times of moral crisis.

verses.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे॥
verses.transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām | dharma-saṁsthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge ||
verses.translation: To deliver the pious and to annihilate the miscreants, as well as to reestablish the principles of dharma, I appear millennium after millennium.
verses.teaching: The divine promise to restore balance between good and evil gives hope and purpose to righteous action in every age.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना॥
verses.transliteration: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam | brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā ||
verses.translation: The act of offering is Brahman; the oblation is Brahman; by Brahman it is offered into the fire of Brahman. Brahman is that which is to be attained by him who performs action pertaining to Brahman.
verses.teaching: The vision of the divine in all activities - seeing everything as sacred transforms ordinary work into spiritual practice and leads to the realization of universal consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्। सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति॥
verses.transliteration: bhoktāraṁ yajña-tapasāṁ sarva-loka-maheśvaram | suhṛdaṁ sarva-bhūtānāṁ jñātvā māṁ śāntim ṛcchati ||
verses.translation: A person in full consciousness of Me, knowing Me to be the ultimate beneficiary of all sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all planets and demigods, and the benefactor and well-wisher of all living entities, attains peace from the pangs of material miseries.
verses.teaching: Peace comes from understanding God as the ultimate beneficiary of all actions and the true friend of all beings. This realization removes the ego and brings inner tranquility.

verses.sanskrit: उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्। आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः॥
verses.transliteration: uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet | ātmaiva hy ātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: One must deliver himself with the help of his mind, and not degrade himself. The mind is the friend of the conditioned soul, and his enemy as well.
verses.teaching: Self-improvement and personal responsibility. The mind can be both our greatest ally and our greatest obstacle in spiritual progress.

verses.sanskrit: तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः। कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन॥
verses.transliteration: tapasvibhyo 'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo 'pi mato 'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaś cādhiko yogī tasmād yogī bhavārjuna ||
verses.translation: A yogi is greater than the ascetic, greater than the empiricist and greater than the fruitive worker. Therefore, O Arjuna, in all circumstances, be a yogi.
verses.teaching: The path of yoga integrates all spiritual practices - devotion, knowledge, and action - making it the most complete path for spiritual realization.

verses.sanskrit: दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया। मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते॥
verses.transliteration: daivī hy eṣā guṇa-mayī mama māyā duratyayā | mām eva ye prapadyante māyām etāṁ taranti te ||
verses.translation: This divine energy of Mine, consisting of the three modes of material nature, is difficult to overcome. But those who have surrendered unto Me can easily cross beyond it.
